data.title: We Are ‘One, No One and a Hundred Thousands’ — and It’s Beautiful
data.meta_description: I have later struggled with the problem of human multidimensionality. I have found myself being many things in one — having different passions and interests that society often perceives as mutually…
data.text:
I have later struggled with the problem of human multidimensionality. I have found myself being many things in one — having different passions and interests that society often perceives as mutually exclusive.

Some days, I want to be a scientist; other days, I want to be a creative writer. Some days I want to live in a big city, while some others I long for the peace of the countryside. I want and need all of this, but at different times, when different parts of me take over.

Then, I realized that for some people who meet me in specific contexts, I am reduced to just one of the many facets I find within myself. My complexity is flattened into a category to help them identify me with something.

I was struggling with these thoughts when I decided it was time to pick up a book I’ve wanted to read for a long time: “One, No One and a Hundred Thousands” by Luigi Pirandello (Nobel Prize for Literature in 1934).

The Plot

Vitangelo Moscarda lives in a small town in Sicily, carrying on with what we could define as a…
